items.title: You can try DeepSeek’s R1 through Perplexity—without the security risk
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Perplexity integrates Chinese company DeepSeek’s R1 model, allowing users to try it without data passing through DeepSeek’s app.
- CEO Aravind Srinivas claims DeepSeek’s models represent a revolutionary moment in AI, despite skepticism from some AI experts.
- Users can access DeepSeek via a menu in Perplexity's interface, which shows the model's "chain of thought" in real-time, a first for AI models.
- DeepSeek R1 avoids politically sensitive discussions and has less stringent data-sharing practices, keeping user data in the U.S. and Canada.

items.title: The value of Trump’s memecoin has dropped more than 75% since inauguration
items.author: Chris Morris
items.summary:
- Trump’s memecoin, $TRUMP, launched just before his inauguration, has seen a significant drop in value.
- The coin fell from an all-time high of $75.35 to $16.63, a loss of more than 75%.
- The market cap of $TRUMP is currently $3.3 billion, down from $14.5 billion prior to the inauguration.
- A memecoin launched by Melania Trump also saw a decline, dropping 88% since its peak.
- The sell-off of $TRUMP coincided with economic fears and ongoing tariff discussions, affecting overall cryptocurrency markets.

items.title: Robinhood halts Super Bowl betting contracts after CFTC request
items.summary:
- Robinhood announced the rollback of event contracts for betting on the Super Bowl after CFTC request.
- The decision comes one day after product launch; Robinhood expressed disappointment.
- CFTC did not classify Kalshi's football contracts as illegal; Robinhood is complying with their directive.
- The contracts were launched to 1% of Robinhood's users, with options for users to close positions or allow resolution.
- Event derivatives trading allows speculation on outcomes of various events like elections and economic releases.

items.title: Apple launches Invites, its event invitation app that takes on Partiful
items.summary:
- Apple launched a new app called [Invites](https://www.apple.com/newsroom/2025/02/introducing-apple-invites-a-new-app-that-brings-people-together/) for iCloud+ subscribers, allowing users to create and share invitations.
- The app integrates Maps and Weather for event details, and users can manage RSVPs, share albums, and collaborate on playlists.
- Invites is available on the App Store for iPhones running iOS 18 or later, and also accessible via [web](https://www.icloud.com/invites/).
- The app competes with Partiful, Paperless Post, and evite, targeting a similar user base, particularly among Gen Z.

items.title: ‘I would love to share affection and attention’: This Facebook group connect families with surrogate grandparents
items.summary:
- Surrogate Grandparents USA is a Facebook group connecting families with surrogate grandparents, allowing them to engage in activities together.
- Founded in 2015 by Donna Skora, the group has over 11,800 members and addresses the loneliness felt by various individuals.
- The platform allows people to post personal ads and connect based on mutual interests before meeting in person.
- Addresses issues like estrangement, with approximately 27% of American adults reporting a cut-off from family members.

items.title: What’s behind Nintendo’s 42% drop in profits?
items.author: Yuri Kageyama
items.summary:
- Nintendo’s profits fell by 42% to 237 billion yen ($1.5 billion) from the previous year, driven by declining Switch console sales.
- Sales dropped 31% to 956 billion yen ($6 billion) for the nine-month period, with total console sales declining from 13.7 million to 9.54 million units.
- The company revised its profit forecast for the fiscal year down to 270 billion yen ($1.7 billion) from 300 billion yen ($1.9 billion).
- Nintendo plans to sell 11 million Switch consoles for the full year, down from an initial projection of 12.5 million.
- Despite declining sales, over 100 million Switch players remain, and Nintendo is launching the successor, Switch 2, later this year.
- The opening of Super Nintendo World in May 2024 is expected to draw interest in Nintendo's content.

items.title: Twitch has plenty of competition in the livestream economy. CEO Dan Clancy isn’t worried
items.summary:
- Dan Clancy, CEO of Twitch, openly discusses competition from platforms like TikTok, YouTube, and Facebook.
- Clancy views Twitch as a competitor in the larger 'market of attention,' not just against other livestreaming sites.
- Twitch holds 61.1% of the livestreaming market but faces rising competition, particularly from YouTube Gaming at 22.9%.
- Twitch's dominance includes 82.3% of total hours streamed but only 60.8% of hours watched.
- Despite difficulties in 2024, including layoffs and shutdowns, Twitch retains its lead over competitors.

items.title: Children’s reading levels are plummeting. Is tech to blame?
items.summary:
- Eighth-grade reading scores in the U.S. are at an all-time low, with 33% scoring 'below basic'.
- This represents a significant decline; in 2013, only 22% were 'below basic'.
- The decrease in reading skills is attributed to technology, particularly smartphones, rather than the quality of teaching.

items.title: This scrappy search upstart is getting thousands of people to give up Google
items.summary:
- Many users perceive Google’s search results as declining in quality, particularly with the rise of AI-generated answers.
- Kagi, a new search engine, offers an alternative to Google by aiming for more reliable and less AI-dependent results.
- The founder of Kagi emphasizes it is not trying to be a 'Google killer', but it has gained traction among early adopters and tech enthusiasts.

items.title: TikTok Users Claim Banana Peels Can Act as a Natural Botox Alternative
items.summary:
- A beauty hack involves rubbing banana peels on the face to tighten and brighten skin.
- TikTok users report positive experiences with this method, likening it to Botox.
- Dermatologist Geeta Yadav advises against using banana peels as a substitute for traditional skincare products.
- While banana peels contain beneficial compounds, they are not a replacement for Botox or scientifically proven skincare solutions.
- Some experts warn banana peel usage could lead to skin irritation, particularly for those with sensitive skin.

items.title: Trump’s Tariffs May Disrupt E-Commerce Growth in the U.S.
items.summary:
- E-commerce's share of retail sales increased from 15% in 2020 to 16.2% by 2024.
- The number of duty-free packages entering the U.S. surpassed one million in 2024.
- Trump imposed a 10% tariff on goods from China, potentially affecting 335 million U.S. citizens relying on e-commerce.
- Trump acknowledged that Americans might experience 'some pain' from the tariffs.
- Experts warn that businesses sourcing from China may face significant challenges due to these tariffs.

items.title: Trump signs order to create a sovereign wealth fund that could buy TikTok
items.author: Donald Trump
items.summary:
- U.S. President Donald Trump signed an executive order to create a sovereign wealth fund that may purchase TikTok.
- Details about the fund's operation are unclear; it will likely require Congressional approval and could be funded through tariffs.
- Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent stated the fund should be established within the next 12 months, aiming to monetize U.S. assets for the American people.

items.title: OpenAI reveals new AI tool that can do online research for you
items.author: Jessica Bursztynsky
items.summary:
- OpenAI introduced a new feature called Deep Research in ChatGPT, enabling it to conduct independent research online.
- The tool claims to analyze and summarize information from various sources, providing citations and a cohesive report.
- Deep Research can complete tasks in 5 to 30 minutes, significantly faster than a human researcher.
- It is currently available to GPT Pro subscribers for $200/month, with plans to expand to other paid services.
- Limitations include potential hallucinations and difficulty distinguishing rumors from authoritative information, with expectations for improvement over time.

items.title: Will a return to OG Facebook appeal to Gen Z?
items.summary:
- Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg hinted at a return to original Facebook during the Q4 earnings call, setting it as a goal for 2025.
- Specific details of what “OG Facebook” entails remain unclear; it could refer to the nostalgic Facebook of the 2010s or its controversial beginnings.
- Zuckerberg noted the need for Facebook to regain cultural influence among younger users, who significantly prefer platforms like TikTok and Snapchat over Facebook.
- Recent studies show only 33% of U.S. teens currently use Facebook, marking a steep decline from 71% a decade ago.
- Meta's previous attempts to attract younger users, such as the flop of Facebook Campus and the Gen Z redesign in October 2024, have not succeeded.

items.title: OpenAI and SoftBank announce artificial intelligence joint venture
items.author: Yuri Kageyama
items.summary:
- OpenAI and SoftBank launched a joint venture, SB OpenAI Japan, with a 50-50 ownership structure.
- SoftBank's Chief Masayoshi Son and OpenAI's Sam Altman announced the venture at an event in Tokyo, inviting Japanese companies to participate.
- SoftBank plans to invest $3 billion annually to integrate its AI service, Cristal, across its companies, starting with its own subsidiaries.
- Cristal aims to enhance planning, marketing, and email functionalities.
- OpenAI's new “deep research” feature will allow ChatGPT to perform complex tasks and will be available in Japanese.
- The partnership aims to transform AI capabilities in significant Japanese companies, and is part of a broader AI infrastructure project backed by Oracle and others.

items.title: The Politics of Getting Your Friends to Untag You in Photos
items.author: Delia Cai, Steffi Cao
items.summary:
- Discusses social media etiquette around being tagged in photos.
- Advises being honest with friends about wanting to be untagged if feeling uncomfortable with a photo.
- Highlights the impact of social media on self-perception and beauty standards.
- Suggests that friends should respect each other's requests regarding photo tagging.
- Offers tips on group chat introductions for better organization.

items.title: Google teams up with Samsung to take on Dolby Atmos
items.summary:
- Google and Samsung announced a new 3D audio format called [Eclipsa Audio](https://opensource.googleblog.com/2025/01/introducing-eclipsa-audio-immersive-audio-for-everyone.html).
- Eclipsa Audio will be available on this year’s Samsung TVs and soundbars, and on YouTube for creators to upload immersive content.
- Unlike Dolby Atmos, Eclipsa Audio will be offered royalty-free to device makers.
- Google's project lead Jani Huoponen emphasizes that spatial audio will become significant in the audio space.
- The concept of spatial audio was first developed in the 1970s, but has gained more traction in recent years due to the growth of streaming services and home theater setups.

items.title: 3 quick ways to free up iPhone storage space
items.summary:
- Clearing storage on iPhone after too many downloads and recordings.
- First tip: Detach from big message attachments via Settings > General > iPhone Storage > Review Large Attachments.
- Second tip: Intelligently offload unused or seldom used apps.

items.title: The Clicks iPhone keyboard is as powerful as it is frustrating
items.summary:
- Clicks keyboard case transforms an iPhone into a Blackberry-like device, enhancing productivity with shortcuts.
- New iPhone 16 versions launched in January feature improved key design, MagSafe support, and USB-C data transfer.
- Priced at $139 for regular-sized iPhones and $159 for Pro Max and Plus models, Clicks remains a niche product despite its capabilities.

items.title: This free music-streaming site can replace your Spotify subscription
items.summary:
- The author expresses nostalgia for listening to the radio instead of modern music-streaming services like Spotify.
- Spotify allows instant access to millions of songs, but can be distracting due to constant interface interaction.
- The excitement arises from discovering a new radio-like music service that provides a classic listening experience with a modern approach.

items.title: OpenAI begins releasing its next generation of reasoning models with o3-mini
items.summary:
- OpenAI released the reasoning model o3-mini, which is more intelligent than o1-mini yet maintains low price and speed.
- o3-mini is accessible through API with three levels of reasoning intensity, catering to varying problem difficulties.
- The model is available for ChatGPT Plus, Team, and Pro users starting today; enterprise users will gain access in a week.
- OpenAI researcher Noam Brown noted that the o3-mini model outperforms the full-sized o1 model in several evaluations.
- The o3 series models, including o3-mini, demonstrate significantly higher intelligence levels in advanced computer coding and problem solving, achieving an 87.5% score on the ARC-AGI test.
- OpenAI emphasizes reasoning capabilities over previous training approaches, aiming for faster and more efficient problem-solving.

items.title: The Hawk Tuah girl remains radio silent after her crypto controversy
items.summary:
- Hailey Welch, known as the 'hawk tuah' girl, has not posted online since late 2024 following a failed cryptocurrency venture.
- Her memecoin, $HAWK, launched on December 4, 2024, skyrocketed to a $490 million market cap but lost $440 million in value within 20 minutes.
- Welch's silence comes after facing backlash and a lawsuit from investors who accused her of a 'rug pull' scam during the launch of her cryptocurrency.

items.title: Airbnb CEO Brian Chesky explains how he helped Sam Altman during OpenAI’s 2023 board fiasco
items.summary:
- Brian Chesky is leading Airbnb through a major reinvention, focusing on expanding beyond its core business.
- Chesky has known Sam Altman for 16 years and provided him support during Altman's tumultuous dismissal from OpenAI.
- Chesky advised Altman on handling public relations and employee concerns after his firing, emphasizing transparency and care for the company’s staff.
- He expressed the importance of protecting founders and ensuring fair processes in Silicon Valley to foster innovation.

items.title: Logan and Jake Paul reveal ‘Paul American’ Max reality show
items.summary:
- The Paul brothers are launching a family reality series, *Paul American*, on HBO Max starting March 27.
- Promotional social media posts led fans to believe they would fight, but it was a hype strategy for the show.
- The series aims to showcase their relationships and Logan's transition into fatherhood, offering a raw and honest perspective.
- Jake Paul stated that the series reveals the truth behind what people think they know about them.
- The show features family members, including their parents and partners, and consists of eight episodes, concluding with a finale on May 15.

items.title: Apple reports dip in iPhone sales over the holidays, despite AI rollout
items.summary:
- Apple reported a 1% drop in iPhone revenue during the October-December holiday quarter compared to the previous year.
- The decline comes as Apple rolls out AI features, which were fully launched just before Halloween, with availability still limited in markets like China.
- Apple's overall revenue reached $124.3 billion, with iPhone revenue at $69.1 billion, but total revenue in China declined 11% year-over-year.
- Competitors Huawei and Xiaomi saw significant growth in China, with Apple’s market share shrinking, reflecting a nearly 10% drop in iPhone shipments.
- CEO Tim Cook announced further AI rollouts in Europe, Japan, and Korea planned for April, while projecting optimistic revenue for the upcoming quarter.

items.title: Italy blocked AI app DeepSeek in Apple and Google stores. Here’s why
items.summary:
- Italy's data protection authority blocked DeepSeek from app stores due to concerns over personal data use.
- The app had recently launched a free AI assistant, surpassing ChatGPT in downloads prior to the ban.
- The Italian regulator is investigating compliance with GDPR and demanded a response from DeepSeek in 20 days regarding data collection practices.

items.title: Capital One’s new AI agent will help you buy your next car
items.summary:
- Capital One has launched a new AI agent called Chat Concierge to assist consumers in buying cars.
- The AI agent helps with research, comparing vehicles, and scheduling test drives to ease the car-buying process.
- The Chat Concierge uses specialized AI agents, aiming to provide a more satisfying and frictionless experience for customers.
- Capital One is expanding the feature to be available nationwide throughout the year.
- Chat Concierge can perform tasks like estimating trade-in values and directly answering customer inquiries about inventory.

items.title: Are you problematic? This ‘cancel culture insurance’ could help you deal with social media backlash
items.summary:
- Insurance agency Samphire Risk introduces "cancel culture" insurance for celebrities and executives facing social media backlash.
- The policy, named Preempt, includes crisis management services to combat negative press for 60 days.
- It offers a 24/7 hotline for immediate damage control and analytical support to identify reputational risks before they escalate.

items.title: If you were bored watching videos at a plodding 2x speed, you’re in luck: They can go faster
How Apple Vision Pro is finding a home in healthcare
items.summary:
- In early 2024, a team of surgeons at UC San Diego Health, led by Dr. Ryan Broderick, criticized the clutter of monitors in operating rooms.
- On February 2, Apple released the Vision Pro headset, allowing doctors to overlay virtual screens in surgery without physical displays.
- A trial involving real patients is ongoing, with over 50 successful cases reported by Dr. Broderick's team.

items.title: What to know about the American Airlines jet and Army helicopter that collided over D.C.
items.summary:
- A Bombardier CRJ700 American Airlines jet and a UH-60 Black Hawk helicopter collided over Washington.
- The jet had 60 passengers and four crew members; the helicopter had three service members on board.
- None are believed to have survived the incident, which resulted in both aircraft crashing into the Potomac River.
- Approximately 5,000 Black Hawks are in service worldwide, manufactured by Sikorsky, a Lockheed Martin subsidiary.
- The Black Hawk has been operational since 1979 and has been involved in numerous military operations, including the raid that killed Osama bin Laden in 2011.

items.title: After a week of DeepSeek freakout, doubts and mysteries remain
items.summary:
- DeepSeek created advanced AI models using less computing power than expected, raising questions about U.S. AI competitiveness.
- The company trained its model for $5.6 million but full costs are undetermined, as preliminary configurations likely required more investment.
- Innovations like Mixture-of-experts architecture and chain-of-thought reasoning may not be unique, as these are common in AI research.
- DeepSeek's methods using the smaller R1 model showed spontaneous reasoning with fewer training resources, raising interest in AI training efficiency.
- Nvidia's stock fell 17% as investors reacted to the implications of DeepSeek's findings, speculating on the future demand for high-end GPUs.
- There are allegations that DeepSeek may have used OpenAI models inappropriately for training, though the evidence remains unconfirmed.
- DeepSeek's breakthroughs may allow more efficient AI applications on consumer devices like smartphones, of interest to companies like Apple.
- OpenAI released an AI tool called ChatGPT Gov for U.S. government agencies, emphasizing secure and private AI use within federal environments.

items.title: Microsoft posts 10% growth for Q4 as it plans to spend $80 billion on AI
items.summary:
- Microsoft reported a 10% profit growth for the October-December quarter, netting $24.1 billion ($3.23/share).  
- Revenue hit $69.6 billion, a 12% increase from the previous year, beating Wall Street's expectations.  
- Cloud sales grew 19% to $25.5 billion, slightly missing projections; productivity segment rose 14% to $29.4 billion.  
- Microsoft plans to spend $80 billion on AI advancements, including expanding data center capacity.  
- Microsoft's stock fell 5% after-hours, influenced by concerns over a competitor, DeepSeek.

items.title: Meta’s Q4 profits exceed Wall Street’s expectations
items.author: null
items.summary:
- Meta reported Q4 profits of $20.83 billion, up 49% year-over-year.
- Revenue grew 21% to $48.39 billion, exceeding analysts' expectations of $47 billion.
- CEO Mark Zuckerberg anticipates significant advancements in AI by 2025, aiming for 1 billion users.
- Meta expects Q1 revenue between $39.5 billion and $41.8 billion, with expenses projected at $114 billion to $119 billion.
- Meta agreed to pay $25 million to settle a lawsuit from Donald Trump related to account suspensions after the January 6 attack.
- Stock rose 2% to $690.02 in after-hours trading.

items.title: Tesla’s Q4 results fell short of Wall Street’s forecasts. Here’s why
items.summary:
- Tesla’s Q4 adjusted profits rose 3% to $2.6 billion (73 cents per share), below analysts' estimate of 77 cents.
- Stock initially fell, then rose over 4% after Elon Musk announced plans for unsupervised full self-driving technology in Austin starting June.
- Quarterly revenue increased by 2% to $25.7 billion, lower than Wall Street’s forecast of $27.1 billion; gross profit margin fell to 16.3%.
- Tesla reported a dramatic 71% drop in unadjusted profits from $7.93 billion in the same quarter the previous year.
- The company sold 1.79 million vehicles in 2024, the first drop in over a decade, though Q4 showed a record sale of 495,570 vehicles.
- Musk emphasized a focus on maximizing vehicle production and a potential path for Tesla to become the most valuable company in the world.

items.title: Reid Hoffman says that AI can give you superpowers
items.summary:
- Reid Hoffman discusses the concept of "superagency" related to AI and its potential to enhance human abilities.
- He emphasizes curiosity over fear regarding AI technology and its societal implications.
- Hoffman compares AI to earlier transformative technologies like cars and phones, highlighting both benefits and changes in human agency.
- He encourages engagement with AI to unlock new opportunities and enhance overall capabilities in society.
- Hoffman believes that adapting to AI will require new skills, and he advocates for intentional design to navigate the technological transition successfully.

items.title: How execs can bridge the AI knowledge gap
items.summary:
- AI is becoming essential in the workplace, aiding in tasks like brainstorming and administration.
- A study by Lucid Software found that over a third of global workers use AI for tasks such as idea generation and content creation.
- Nearly two-thirds of employees see AI as a path to better work-life balance and enhances productivity.
- Key benefits of AI identified: productivity gains (62%), cost savings (40%), and improved communication (38%).
- More than 50% believe AI could save them three hours of work weekly, allowing focus on strategic initiatives.
- Despite excitement about AI, many users feel overwhelmed by the variety of tools available, highlighting the need for seamless integration into existing workflows.

items.title: Amazon secretly tracked Californian consumers via cellphones, lawsuit alleges
items.author: Felix Kolotinsky
items.summary:
- Amazon was sued for allegedly tracking consumers' movements via cellphones and selling collected data.
- The lawsuit claims Amazon accessed phones through the Amazon Ads SDK provided to app developers.
- The complaint states Amazon collected sensitive geolocation data without consumer consent, revealing personal information.
- The lawsuit was filed by Felix Kolotinsky, seeking unspecified damages for millions of Californians.

items.title: This group is playing ‘Dungeons & Dragons’ to help L.A. fire victims, and you can join in
items.author: Ashley Johnson, Marisha Ray, Taliesin Jaffe, Travis Willingham, Sam Riegel, Bobbie Daymond, Laura Bailey, Liam O’Brien, Matthew Mercer
items.summary:
• Critical Role is hosting a charity Dungeons & Dragons event titled “Freaky Thursday” on January 30 at 7 p.m. PT.
• The event features characters from their third D&D campaign and aims to raise $180,000 for wildfire recovery efforts in California.
• Donations will be split between several foundations and will influence the game experience through community contributions via Tiltify.

items.title: TikTok's Punch Card Hack for New Year Resolutions
items.summary:
- TikTok creator @emiliamariehome shared a viral video about using punch cards to motivate achieving goals, gaining over 1.5 million views.
- The punch card concept involves setting personal goals and rewarding completion by punching holes in the card, which users find satisfying.
- Examples include rewarding oneself with new kitchen items or treats based on achieving dating or cooking goals.
- The trend aligns with New Year goal-setting, as many people set ambitious resolutions but often abandon them by the end of January.

items.title: Alibaba rolls out AI model, claiming it’s better than DeepSeek-V3
The rise of ‘influencer voice’: Why this TikTok creator accent is taking over the internet and maybe the world
items.summary:
- The 'influencer accent' is becoming prominent on TikTok, characterized by a rising tone at the end of sentences.
- British singer-songwriter Cassyette highlighted this trend in a TikTok video with over 1.2 million views.
- American influencers have been adapting this speaking style, combining elements of various accents and vocal techniques, including a 'valley girl' influence and vocal fry.

items.title: After DeepSeek, the AI giants still have plenty of work left to do
items.author: Harry McCracken
items.summary:
• Chinese startup DeepSeek released its R1 AI model on January 20, 2025, potentially rivaling OpenAI's GPT-o1 despite lower resources.
• The launch led to increased stock market activity for Nvidia and sparked discussions on AI resource competition and geopolitical implications.
• DeepSeek is openly publishing its methods and technologies, contrasting with the secrecy of historical rivals in the space race, indicating a shift in AI development dynamics.
• Current AI applications lag behind advancements in large language models (LLMs), with examples like Microsoft's Copilot needing further improvement.
• The aspiration for agentic AI remains a work in progress, as seen with recent releases from OpenAI and Google struggling with basic tasks.

items.title: AI assistants for lawyers are a booming business—with big risks
items.summary:
- Illinois lawyer Mathew Kerbis uses AI tools for legal research and document drafting.
- He offers subscription-based legal services and emphasizes speed for client satisfaction.
- Paxton AI, a startup that recently secured $22 million in funding, helps lawyers draft documents and analyze contracts efficiently.
- Competitors include established firms like LexisNexis and Thomson Reuters aiming to utilize AI for legal tasks.
- The goal is to enhance the work efficiency of young attorneys by utilizing AI.

items.title: DeepSeek Questions Big AI’s Trillion-Dollar Assumption
items.summary:
- Chinese startup [DeepSeek](https://www.fastcompany.com/91267354/deepseek-explained-china-llm-chatgpt-nvidia-microsoft-stock-ai-rattled) developed advanced AI models using significantly less computing power.
- DeepSeek challenged the prevailing belief that more computing power leads to better AI models, suggesting the approach to AGI could be overhauled.
- OpenAI CEO Sam Altman has advocated for substantial investment in computing power, recently stating a need for $7 trillion to build necessary data centers for AGI.
- Unlike OpenAI, DeepSeek shares access to its models, allowing developers to build on its research, but faces challenges due to U.S. chip bans and funding constraints.
- Some industry figures, including Andrej Karpathy of OpenAI, remain skeptical and still advocate for the importance of compute power for achieving higher intelligence in AI.

items.title: How DeepSeek answers questions on China differently than ChatGPT
items.summary:
- Chinese startup DeepSeek has launched an AI chatbot that competes with OpenAI's ChatGPT.
- The chatbot became the No. 1 downloaded free app on Apple's iPhone store upon its launch.
- DeepSeek's chatbot appears to censor sensitive topics, reflecting common practices on China's Internet.
- China's regulations require AI products to undergo security reviews before public launches.

items.title: DashCon, the infamous celebration of Tumblr fandom, is coming back. This time, organizers say it will be different
items.author: Avis, Simone
items.summary:
- DashCon, originally held in 2014, aimed to unite the Tumblr community.
- The first event ended in financial crisis, leading to its notoriety as an internet failure.
- A new event, DashCon 2, is being organized—not as a Tumblr convention, but as an internet history con, focusing on a specific era of fandom.
- The new organizers pledge to avoid the mistakes of the first event and celebrate current artists and creators.

items.title: Boom Supersonic’s XB-1 breaks the sound barrier—the first private aircraft to do so
items.summary:
- Boom Supersonic’s XB-1 became the first privately funded airplane to break the sound barrier during a test flight over the Mojave Desert.
- Chief Test Pilot Tristan “Geppetto” Brandenburg reported the aircraft flew successfully at Mach 1.1 (about 845 mph).
- The XB-1 is a precursor to the Overture, a planned supersonic airliner designed to carry 64-80 passengers across the Atlantic in approximately 3.5 hours.
- Boom Supersonic has received 130 orders and pre-orders from American Airlines, United Airlines, and Japan Airlines.
- The company recently completed construction of its Overture Superfactory in Greensboro, North Carolina, aiming to produce 66 Overture aircraft annually.

items.title: OpenAI announces more secure ChatGPT for government workers, Trump administration
items.summary:
- OpenAI launched a new ChatGPT system called ChatGPT Gov for U.S. government workers, emphasizing enhanced security over the Enterprise version.
- It allows government agencies to input sensitive nonpublic data while self-hosting to manage security and compliance.
- Over 90,000 government users have already sent 18 million messages using ChatGPT since early 2024.
- The announcement coincides with the beginning of Donald Trump's new administration, with OpenAI's Sam Altman attending the inauguration and discussing AI's importance.

items.title: ‘Grave concern’ for cables in the Baltic Sea as NATO ramps up its guard
items.summary:
- NATO increases surveillance in the Baltic Sea due to rising concerns over damaged underwater cables and pipelines.
- A new mission named “Baltic Sentry” is launched to protect critical underwater infrastructure.
- 11 cables have been reported damaged since October 2023, raising suspicions of deliberate sabotage amidst ongoing geopolitical tensions with Russia.
- Investigations suggest recent damage may be accidental, caused by ships and anchors, rather than deliberate attacks.
